contentrichtext.text: {{refimprove|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox monarch | name =King Samsenethai | title =King of Lan Xang | image = | caption = | reign =1372–1417 | coronation = | predecessor =[[Fa Ngum]] | successor =[[Lan Kham Deng]] | heir = | consort = Princess Ngo Fa of Ayutthaya <br /> Princess [[Noy Onsa]] of [[Lan Na]]. | issue = Princess [[Keo Koumari]] <br /> Princess [[Anousa]]<br /> Princess [[Manora]] <br /> Princess [[Souphutta]] <br /> Princess [[Siva Yaka]] <br /> Prince [[Lan Kham Deng]] <br />Prince [[Sai (prince)|Sai]] <br /> Prince [[Khamteam]] <br /> Prince [[Kongkeo]] <br />Prince [[Leu Xay]] <br /> Prince [[Fa Kheun]] | othertitles = | royal house =[[Lan Xang]] | royal anthem = | father =[[Fa Ngum]] | mother = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | buried = |}} '''Samsenethai''' (also called '''Oun Huan''') was the second king of [[Lan Xang]], the son of [[Fa Ngum]], whom he succeeded.<ref>http://www.royalark.net/Laos/lanxang1.htm</ref> He ruled from 1372 until 1417. The origin of the name Samsenethai is thought to be a reflection of the political and social upheaval occurring within the area at the time of his rule. Samsenethai literally means "300,000 Thai," thus reflected the result of a census conducted in his reign. It is unclear whether the census included the entire population or just men capable of bearing arms. {{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} There is also discussion as to whether during this period, the terms "Thai" and "Lao" were interchangeable, whether the term "Lao" yet{{explanation needed}} existed, or whether "Thai" was used in his name to refer to the fact that the census included all [[Tai peoples|Tai]] groups. For the duration of 43 year reign, Lan Xang did not fight a single battle. {{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} Samsenethai had five daughters; Princess [[Keo Koumari]], Princess [[Anousa]], Princess [[Manora (princess)|Manôra]], Princess [[Souphutta]], and Princess [[Siva Yaka]]. He had three sons by Princess [[Ngo Fa]] of Ayutthaya; Prince [[Lan Kham Dèng]], Prince [[Prince Sai|Sai]], Prince [[Khamtèm]]. His other sons, Prince [[Kongkèo]], Prince [[Lu Xay]], and Prince [[Fa Kheun]]'s mother was Princess [[Noy Onsa]] of [[Lan Na]]. [[Wat Manorom]], [[Wat Oubôsôt]], and [[Wat Xiang Kham]] were built in Samsenethai's reign. He was succeeded by his son Lan Kham Deng. {{s-start}} {{s-hou|[[Monarchs of Laos|Lan Xang]]|}} {{succession box|title=[[King of Lan Xang]]|before=[[Fa Ngum]] |after=[[Lan Kham Deng]]|years='''1373–1416'''}} {{s-end}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Samsenethai | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = King of Lan Xang | DATE OF BIRTH = | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1416 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} [[Category:1416 deaths]] [[Category:History of Laos]] [[Category:Tai history]] [[Category:Laotian royalty]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] {{Laos-bio-stub}} {{SEAsia-hist-stub}} {{Noble-stub}}
